    Summary of Notation

    1. Capital letters: random variables
    2. Lowercase letters: values of random variables & for scalar functions.
    3. Quantities that are required to be real-valued vectors are written in bold and in lowercase (even if random variables). Matrices are bold capitals.
    4. Abbreviations: - for disadvantages, + for advantages, sol for solution, nw for network

    Symbols

    • =.\overset{.}{=}=.: equality relationship that is true by definition
    • â‰ˆ\approxâ‰ˆ: approximately equal
    • âˆ\proptoâˆ: proportional to
    • Pr{X=x}Pr\{X = x\}Pr{X=x}: probability that a random variable XXX takes on the value xxx
    • Xâˆ¼pX \sim pXâˆ¼p: random variable XXX selected from distribution p(x)p(x)p(x)
    • E[X]E[X]E[X]: expectation of a random variable XXX, i.e., E[X]=.âˆ‘xp(x)xE[X] \overset{.}{=} \sum_x p(x)xE[X]=.âˆ‘xâ€‹p(x)x
    • argâ¡maxâ¡af(a)\arg\max_{a} f(a)argmaxaâ€‹f(a): a value of aaa at which f(a)f(a)f(a) takes its maximal value
    • lnâ¡x\ln xlnx: natural logarithm of xxx
    • exe^xex: the base of the natural logarithm, eâ‰ˆ2.71828e \approx 2.71828eâ‰ˆ2.71828, carried to power xxx; elnâ¡x=xe^{\ln x} = xelnx=x
    • R\mathbb{R}R: set of real numbers
    • f:Xâ†’Yf: X \to Yf:Xâ†’Y: function fff from elements of set $ X $ to elements of set $ Y $
    • (a,b](a, b](a,b]: the real interval between aaa and bbb including bbb but not including aaa

    Parameters

    • Ïµ\epsilonÏµ: probability of taking a random action in an $ \epsilon $-greedy policy
    • Î±,Î²\alpha, \betaÎ±,Î²: step-size parameters
    • Î³\gammaÎ³: discount-rate parameter
    • Î»\lambdaÎ»: decay-rate parameter for eligibility traces
    • 1predicate\mathbb{1}_\text{predicate}1predicateâ€‹: indicator function. = 1 if the predicate is true, else 0.

    1 Introduction

    2 Multi-Armed Bandit Problem

    • kkk: number of actions (arms)
    • ttt: discrete time step or play number
    • qâˆ—(a)q_*(a)qâˆ—â€‹(a): true value (expected reward) of action $ a $
    • Qt(a)Q_t(a)Qtâ€‹(a): estimate at time $ t $ of $ q_*(a) $
    • Nt(a)N_t(a)Ntâ€‹(a): number of times action $ a $ has been selected up to time $ t $
    • Ht(a)H_t(a)Htâ€‹(a): learned preference for selecting action $ a $ at time $ t $
    • Ï€t(a)\pi_t(a)Ï€tâ€‹(a): probability of selecting action $ a $ at time $ t $
    • RË‰t\bar{R}_tRË‰tâ€‹: estimate at time $ t $ of the expected reward given $ \pi_t $

    3 Markov Decision Process

    TODO: å¯»æ‰¾æœ€ä¼˜piçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚ The reinforcement learning agent and its environment interact over a sequence of discrete time steps. Everything inside the agent is completely known and controllable by the agent; everything outside is incompletely controllable but may or may not be completely known.The agentâ€™s objective is to maximize the amount of reward it receives over time.

    Markov Process is a stochastic process with Markov property: The future is independent of the past given the present.

    • ttt: discrete time step.
    • s,Â sâ€™Â :Â currentÂ state,Â nextÂ state\color{turquoise}\text{s, s' : current state, next state}s,Â sâ€™Â :Â currentÂ state,Â nextÂ state, basisÂ forÂ makingÂ theÂ choices\color{turquoise}\text{basis for making the choices}basisÂ forÂ makingÂ theÂ choices
    • aaa: an action made my the agent
    • $\color{turquoise}\text{ r} $: a reward, basisÂ forÂ evaluatingÂ theÂ choices\color{turquoise}\text{basis for evaluating the choices}basisÂ forÂ evaluatingÂ theÂ choices
    • SSS: set of all nonterminal states
    • S+S^+S+: set of all states, including the terminal state
    • A(s)A(s)A(s): set of all actions available in state $ s $
    • RRR: set of all possible rewards, a finite subset of $ \mathbb{R} $
    • ÏâŠ†R\rho \subseteq \mathbb{R}ÏâŠ†R: subset of $ \mathbb{R} $
    • âˆ£Sâˆ£|S|âˆ£Sâˆ£: number of elements in set $ S $
    • T,T(t)T, T(t)T,T(t) final time step of an episode; the episode including time step t.
    • A(t)A(t)A(t) : Action at t
    • S(t)S(t)S(t) : state at t
    • R(t)R(t)R(t) : reward at t
    • $\color{turquoise} \pi $ : policy (stochastic decision-making rule),is a mappingÂ fromÂ statesÂ toÂ actions\color{turquoise}\text{mapping from states to actions}mappingÂ fromÂ statesÂ toÂ actions
    • Ï€(s)\pi(s)Ï€(s) : action taken in state s under deterministic policy Ï€\piÏ€
    • Ï€(aâˆ£s)\pi(a|s)Ï€(aâˆ£s) : probability of taking action a in state s under stochastic policy Ï€\piÏ€

    MarkovÂ DecisionÂ ProcessÂ (MDP)\color{yellow}\text{Markov Decision Process (MDP)}MarkovÂ DecisionÂ ProcessÂ (MDP) is a mathematical framework used to describe an environment in decision-making scenarios where outcomes are partly random and partly under the control of a decision-maker.

    P[St+1=P[St+1âˆ£S1,...,St]P[St+1âˆ£St,At] P[S_\text{t+1}=P[S_\text{t+1}|S_1,...,S_t]\\P[S_\text{t+1}|S_t,A_t] P[St+1â€‹=P[St+1â€‹âˆ£S1â€‹,...,Stâ€‹]P[St+1â€‹âˆ£Stâ€‹,Atâ€‹]

    ExpectedÂ returnÂ Gt\color{orange}\text{Expected return }G_tExpectedÂ returnÂ Gtâ€‹

    • function of future rewards, long term, that the agent seeks to maximize (in expected value).
    • undiscounted formula: Gt=Rt+1+Rt+2+Rt+3+...+RTG_t= R_\text{t+1}+R_\text{t+2}+R_\text{t+3}+...+R_\text{T}Gtâ€‹=Rt+1â€‹+Rt+2â€‹+Rt+3â€‹+...+RTâ€‹ appropriate for episodic tasks (interaction does not naturally break into episodes but continues without limit.)
    • discounted formula: Gt=Rt+1+Î³Rt+2+Î³2Rt+3+...+RT=âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³kRt+k+1=Rt+1+Î³Gt+1G_t= R_\text{t+1}+\gamma R_\text{t+2}+\gamma^2R_\text{t+3}+...+R_\text{T}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \gamma^kR_\text{t+k+1}=R_\text{t+1}+\gamma G_\text{t+1}Gtâ€‹=Rt+1â€‹+Î³Rt+2â€‹+Î³2Rt+3â€‹+...+RTâ€‹=âˆ‘k=0âˆâ€‹Î³kRt+k+1â€‹=Rt+1â€‹+Î³Gt+1â€‹, appropriate for continuing tasks (Xbreaks into episode, continue without limitation).
      • Note that although the return is a sum of an infinite number of terms, it is still finite if the reward is nonzero and constantâ€”if < 1. For example, if the reward is a constant +1

        Gt=âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³kRt+k+1=âˆ‘k=0âˆÎ³k=11âˆ’Î³ G_t=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \gamma^kR_\text{t+k+1}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\gamma^k = \frac{1}{1-\gamma} Gtâ€‹=k=0âˆ‘âˆâ€‹Î³kRt+k+1â€‹=k=0âˆ‘âˆâ€‹Î³k=1âˆ’Î³1â€‹

    $\color {yellow} G_t \text{ Def in lecture } $$G_t=R_t+\gamma R_\text{t+1}+\gamma2R_\text{t+2}+...=\sum_{k=0}{\infty}\gamma^kR_\text{t+k} $

    Ï€â€™sÂ ValueÂ Functions\color {orange}\pi \text{'s Value Functions}Ï€â€™sÂ ValueÂ Functions assign values to: s, (s,a), exp return from that sate, (s,a)|Ï€\piÏ€

    • vÏ€(s)v_\pi(s)vÏ€â€‹(s): value of state sss under policy Ï€\piÏ€ (expected return)
    • vâˆ—(s)v_*(s)vâˆ—â€‹(s): value of state sss under the optimal policy (its value functions are optimal).
      • optimal value f for s & (s,a) are unique for a MDP, but there can be many optimal Ï€\piÏ€
      • Any policy that is greedy with respect to the optimal value functions must be an optimal policy.
    • qÏ€(s,a)q_\pi(s, a)qÏ€â€‹(s,a): value of taking action aaa in state sss while following policy Ï€\piÏ€
    • qâˆ—(s,a)q_*(s, a)qâˆ—â€‹(s,a): value of taking action aaa in state sss while following the optimal policy
      q statnds for quality, distinguised from state-value f

    BellmanÂ equationÂ forÂ stateÂ valuesÂ vÏ€\color{orange}\text{Bellman equation for state values } v_\piBellmanÂ equationÂ forÂ stateÂ valuesÂ vÏ€â€‹ The value function vÏ€v_\pivÏ€â€‹ s Bellman equation.

    Starting from state s, the root node at the top, the agent could take any of some set of actions (e.g.3) based on its policy pi. 
From each of these, the environment could respond with one of several next states, s0 (e.g.2), 
along with a reward, r, depending on its dynamics given by the function p.

    vÏ€(s)=EÏ€[Gtâˆ£s]=EÏ€[Rt+1+Î³Gt+1âˆ£S=s]=âˆ‘aÏ€(aâˆ£s)âˆ‘sâ€™,rp(sâ€²,râˆ£s,a)[r+Î³vÏ€(sâ€²)]Â forÂ allÂ sâˆˆS v_\pi(s)=E_\pi[G_t|s] =E_\pi[R_\text{t+1}+\gamma G_\text{t+1}|S=s] =\sum_a\pi(a|s)\sum_\text{s',r}p(s',r|s,a)[r+\gamma v_\pi(s')] \text{ for all s} \in S vÏ€â€‹(s)=EÏ€â€‹[Gtâ€‹âˆ£s]=EÏ€â€‹[Rt+1â€‹+Î³Gt+1â€‹âˆ£S=s]=aâˆ‘â€‹Ï€(aâˆ£s)sâ€™,râˆ‘â€‹p(sâ€²,râˆ£s,a)[r+Î³vÏ€â€‹(sâ€²)]Â forÂ allÂ sâˆˆS

    If we were to take action ğ‘ in state ğ‘ , what is the expected return if we then follow ğœ‹ afterward?

    qÏ€(s,a)=EÏ€[Gtâˆ£s,a]=EÏ€[Rt+1+Î³Gt+1âˆ£S=s,A=a]=âˆ‘rp(sâ€²,râˆ£s,a)[r+Î³vÏ€(sâ€²)]âˆ‘sâ€™,aÏ€(aâ€²âˆ£sâ€²) q_\pi(s,a) =E_\pi[G_t|s,a] =E_\pi[R_\text{t+1}+\gamma G_\text{t+1}|S=s, A=a] =\sum_rp(s',r|s,a)[r+\gamma v_\pi(s')]\sum_\text{s',a}\pi(a'|s') qÏ€â€‹(s,a)=EÏ€â€‹[Gtâ€‹âˆ£s,a]=EÏ€â€‹[Rt+1â€‹+Î³Gt+1â€‹âˆ£S=s,A=a]=râˆ‘â€‹p(sâ€²,râˆ£s,a)[r+Î³vÏ€â€‹(sâ€²)]sâ€™,aâˆ‘â€‹Ï€(aâ€²âˆ£sâ€²)

    BellmanÂ optimalityÂ equation\color{orange}\text{Bellman optimality equation}BellmanÂ optimalityÂ equation :the value of a state under an optimal policy must equal the expected return for the best action from that state

    ApporximationsÂ forÂ valueÂ f,Â policy,Â models\color{orange}\text{Apporximations for value f, policy, models}ApporximationsÂ forÂ valueÂ f,Â policy,Â models

    Even if the agent has a complete and accurate environment model, the agent is typically unable to perform enough computation (memory) per time step to fully use it.

    6 Value-based DRL

    è¿™ä¸€è®²ç»ˆäºè·³è„±å‡ºäº†å‰é¢ä¼ ç»Ÿçš„å¼ºåŒ–å­¦ä¹ ï¼ˆè§£å†³ç›¸å¯¹ç®€å•çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼‰ï¼Œç”¨ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œæ‹ŸåˆQ, Vå‡½æ•°ï¼Œé€‚ç”¨äºæ›´å¤§çš„çŠ¶æ€ç©ºé—´ã€‚

    DQNÂ family\large \color{violet}\text{DQN family}DQNÂ family

    Q-Learning: learns a function QÎ¸(s,a)Q_\theta(s,a)QÎ¸â€‹(s,a) with para Î¸\thetaÎ¸

    • given a segment

    • targetÂ \color{turquoise}\text{target }targetÂ  y=r+Î³maxaâ€™QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²)y=r+\gamma max_\text{a'}Q_\theta(s',a')y=r+Î³maxaâ€™â€‹QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²)

    • update:

      QÎ¸(s,a)â†QÎ¸(s,a)+Î±(r+Î³maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²)âˆ’QÎ¸(s,a)) Q_\theta(s,a) \leftarrow Q_\theta(s,a)+\alpha(r+\gamma \max\limits_{a'}Q_\theta(s',a')-Q_\theta(s,a)) QÎ¸â€‹(s,a)â†QÎ¸â€‹(s,a)+Î±(r+Î³aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²)âˆ’QÎ¸â€‹(s,a))

      Î±åé¢ç±»ä¼¼æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™

    • optimization objective:

      Î¸âˆ—â†argminâ¡Î¸E(s,a,sâ€™,r)Â âˆ¼Â U(D)12[(r+Î³maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²))âˆ’QÎ¸(s,a)]2 \theta^* \leftarrow arg \min_\theta E_\text{(s,a,s',r) âˆ¼ U(D)} \frac{1}{2}[(r+\gamma \max\limits_{a'}Q_\theta(s',a'))-Q_\theta(s,a)]^2 Î¸âˆ—â†argÎ¸minâ€‹E(s,a,sâ€™,r)Â âˆ¼Â U(D)â€‹21â€‹[(r+Î³aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²))âˆ’QÎ¸â€‹(s,a)]2

      • (r+Î³maxaâ€™QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²)(r+\gamma max_\text{a'}Q_\theta(s',a')(r+Î³maxaâ€™â€‹QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²) TD target, no gradient here???
      • (s,a,sâ€™,r)Â âˆ¼Â U(D)\text{(s,a,s',r) âˆ¼ U(D)}(s,a,sâ€™,r)Â âˆ¼Â U(D): a transition (state, action, next state, reward) is randomly sampled from the replay buffer D using a uniform distribution U.
      • QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²)Q_\theta(s',a')QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²) å¦‚æœä¸å›ºå®šï¼Œä¼šè¿ç»­æ›´æ–°ï¼Œä¸ç¨³å®š

    DeepÂ Q-NetworksÂ (DQN)\color{orange}\text{Deep Q-Networks (DQN)}DeepÂ Q-NetworksÂ (DQN) represents Q function QÎ¸(s,a)Q_\theta(s,a)QÎ¸â€‹(s,a) by using neural networks.

    • Input:s. Notï¼ˆs,a), because too large
    • Last layer: a. #of elements âˆ£Aâˆ£|A|âˆ£Aâˆ£
    • Output:(s,a)

    -:

    • unstable
      • continuously sampled (s,a,s',r) is not IID
      • QÎ¸(sâ€²,aâ€²)Q_\theta(s',a')QÎ¸â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²) updates freq
    • output is discrete (only fit for discrete action space)

    sol:

    • Experience replay: non IID data -> IID data
      • Store sample et=(st,at,st+1,rt)e_t = (s_t, a_t, s_\text{t+1}, r_t)etâ€‹=(stâ€‹,atâ€‹,st+1â€‹,rtâ€‹) in each step of training INTO replay buffer D.
      • Sampling, uniformly distributed
    • Build 2 nw:

      • Evaluations nw: QÎ¸(s,a)Q_\theta(s,a)QÎ¸â€‹(s,a)

      • Target nw QÎ¸âˆ’(s,a)Q_{\theta^-}(s,a)QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(s,a) to compute TD target: synchronize with the evaluation nw every C step

        • targetÂ \color{turquoise}\text{target }targetÂ  y=r+Î³maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸âˆ’(sâ€²,aâ€²)y=r+\gamma \max\limits_{a'} Q_{\theta^-}(s',a')y=r+Î³aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²)

    Algorithm:

    1. Randomly initialize evaluation network Î¸;Î¸âˆ’â†Î¸\theta; \theta^- \leftarrow \thetaÎ¸;Î¸âˆ’â†Î¸
    2. Initialize experience replay buffer D
    3. Repeat until convergence{

    • Get initial state s0s_0s0â€‹

    • For each step t=0,1,...,T

      • take action ata_tatâ€‹ by Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-greedy based on QÎ¸Q_\thetaQÎ¸â€‹
      • Get reward rtr_trtâ€‹ and the next state st+1s_{t+1}st+1â€‹
      • Store (st,at,st+1,rts_t, a_t, s_{t+1}, r_tstâ€‹,atâ€‹,st+1â€‹,rtâ€‹) in D
      • If D is large enough, sampling N samples {(st,at,st+1,rt)}i=1N\{(s_t, a_t, s_{t+1}, r_t)\}^N_{i=1}{(stâ€‹,atâ€‹,st+1â€‹,rtâ€‹)}i=1Nâ€‹
      • For each sample, calculate target yi=ri+Î³maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸âˆ’(si+1,aâ€²)y_i =r_i+ \gamma \max\limits_{a'} Q_{\theta^-}(s_{i+1},a')yiâ€‹=riâ€‹+Î³aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(si+1â€‹,aâ€²)
      • Update Î¸\thetaÎ¸ by minimize loss L=12Nâˆ‘i(yiâˆ’QÎ¸(si,ai))2L = \frac{1}{2N}\sum_i(y_i-Q_\theta(s_i,a_i))^2L=2N1â€‹âˆ‘iâ€‹(yiâ€‹âˆ’QÎ¸â€‹(siâ€‹,aiâ€‹))2
      • If t mod C=0, then update Î¸âˆ’â†Î¸\theta^- \leftarrow \thetaÎ¸âˆ’â†Î¸ }

    DoubleÂ DQNÂ (DDQN)\color{orange}\text{Double DQN (DDQN)}DoubleÂ DQNÂ (DDQN),improved version of DQN

    Due to the Jensen's inequality, max operation makes the est Q always larger than real Q value. And it will be more serious when #candidate actions increase.

    E[Q^(s,a)]=Q(s,a)E[maxâ¡aQ^(s,a)]â‰¥maxâ¡aQ(s,a) E[\hat Q(s,a)]=Q(s,a) \\E[\max\limits_{a} \hat Q(s,a)] \ge \max\limits_{a} Q(s,a) E[Q^â€‹(s,a)]=Q(s,a)E[amaxâ€‹Q^â€‹(s,a)]â‰¥amaxâ€‹Q(s,a)

    maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸âˆ’(sâ€²,aâ€²)=QÎ¸âˆ’(sâ€²,argmaxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸âˆ’(sâ€²,aâ€²))=E[Râˆ£sâ€²,argmaxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸âˆ’(sâ€²,aâ€²),Î¸âˆ’]â‰¥maxâ¡(E[Râˆ£sâ€²,a1,Î¸âˆ’],E[Râˆ£sâ€²,a2,Î¸âˆ’],...aiâˆˆA \max\limits_{a'}Q_{\theta^-}(s',a')=Q_{\theta^{-}}(s', arg \max\limits_{a'}Q_{\theta^-}(s',a')) \\=E[R|s', arg \max\limits_{a'}Q_{\theta^-}(s',a'),{\theta^-}] \\ \ge \max(E[R|s', a_1,{\theta^-}], E[R|s', a_2,{\theta^-}],... a_i \in A aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²)=QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(sâ€²,argaâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²))=E[Râˆ£sâ€²,argaâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(sâ€²,aâ€²),Î¸âˆ’]â‰¥max(E[Râˆ£sâ€²,a1â€‹,Î¸âˆ’],E[Râˆ£sâ€²,a2â€‹,Î¸âˆ’],...aiâ€‹âˆˆA

    WhereÂ E[maxâ¡(X1,X2)]â‰¥maxâ¡(E[X1],E[X2]) \text{Where } E[\max(X_1, X_2)] \ge \max(E[X_1], E[X_2]) WhereÂ E[max(X1â€‹,X2â€‹)]â‰¥max(E[X1â€‹],E[X2â€‹])

    In DDQN, QÎ¸Q_\thetaQÎ¸â€‹ is used to select next action.

    PrioritizedÂ ExperienceÂ Replay\color{pink}\text{Prioritized Experience Replay}PrioritizedÂ ExperienceÂ Replay : find more experience samples

    Calculate the priority ptp_tptâ€‹ (value of learning)

    pt=âˆ£rt+Î³QÎ¸âˆ’(st+1,argmaxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸(st+1,aâ€²))âˆ’QÎ¸(st,at)âˆ£ p_t = |r_t + \gamma Q_{\theta^-}(s_{t+1}, arg \max\limits_{a'}Q_\theta(s_\text{t+1},a'))-Q_\theta(s_t,a_t)| ptâ€‹=âˆ£rtâ€‹+Î³QÎ¸âˆ’â€‹(st+1â€‹,argaâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸â€‹(st+1â€‹,aâ€²))âˆ’QÎ¸â€‹(stâ€‹,atâ€‹)âˆ£

    Store experience et=(st,at,st+1,rt,pt+Ïµ)e_t = (s_t, a_t,s_\text{t+1},r_t, p_t+\epsilon)etâ€‹=(stâ€‹,atâ€‹,st+1â€‹,rtâ€‹,ptâ€‹+Ïµ) , Ïµ\epsilonÏµ is the noise for randomness, in replay buffer to give each sample a chance to be sampled.

    Prob of ete_tetâ€‹ being selected is P(t)=(ptÎ±)/(âˆ‘kpkÎ±)P(t)=(p_t^\alpha)/(\sum_kp_k^\alpha)P(t)=(ptÎ±â€‹)/(âˆ‘kâ€‹pkÎ±â€‹). Î± for smoothing. (=0 in uniform sampling)

    Weight in importance sampling wt=(NÃ—P(t))âˆ’Î²/(maxâ¡iwi)w_t=(N\times P(t))^{-\beta}/(\max\limits_{i} w_i)wtâ€‹=(NÃ—P(t))âˆ’Î²/(imaxâ€‹wiâ€‹)

    DuelingÂ DQN\color{orange}\text{Dueling DQN}DuelingÂ DQN, improved version of DQN. parallel with DDQN

    Inputs of s are processed by CNN to extract features.

    Core:Advantage funciton A

    AÏ€(s,a)=QÏ€(s,a)âˆ’VÏ€(s)QÏ€(s,a)=E[Gtâˆ£s,a]VÏ€(s)=Eaâˆ¼Ï€(â‹…âˆ£s)[QÏ€(s,a)] A^\pi(s,a)=Q^\pi(s,a)-V^\pi(s)\\Q^\pi(s,a)=E[G_t|s,a]\\V^\pi(s)=E_{a âˆ¼ \pi(Â·|s)}[Q^\pi(s,a)] AÏ€(s,a)=QÏ€(s,a)âˆ’VÏ€(s)QÏ€(s,a)=E[Gtâ€‹âˆ£s,a]VÏ€(s)=Eaâˆ¼Ï€(â‹…âˆ£s)â€‹[QÏ€(s,a)]

    VÏ€(s)Â isÂ theÂ avagerageÂ valueÂ ofÂ QÏ€(s,a).Â AÏ€(s,a)Â measuresÂ theÂ effectÂ afterÂ takingÂ anÂ action.V^\pi(s) \text{ is the avagerage value of }Q^\pi(s,a)\text{. }A^\pi(s,a) \text{ measures the effect after taking an action.}VÏ€(s)Â isÂ theÂ avagerageÂ valueÂ ofÂ QÏ€(s,a).Â AÏ€(s,a)Â measuresÂ theÂ effectÂ afterÂ takingÂ anÂ action.

    To obtain V, A separately (fc layer), Q in the DQN is decomposed. And they are combined into Q finally. Subscript denotes parameters.

    QÎ¸,Î±,Î²(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±(s)+AÎ¸,Î²(s,a) Q_{\theta,\alpha,\beta}(s,a) = V_{\theta,\alpha}(s)+A_{\theta,\beta}(s,a) QÎ¸,Î±,Î²â€‹(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±â€‹(s)+AÎ¸,Î²â€‹(s,a)

    However, this version is unstable in training because the non-uniqueness in modeling V and A.

    For sol 1, max two sides of Q=V+A (max limits a only operates the f with para a), define the optimal A function(maxâ¡aA(s,a)âˆ’maxâ¡aA(s,a)\max\limits_aA(s,a)-\max\limits_aA(s,a)amaxâ€‹A(s,a)âˆ’amaxâ€‹A(s,a)) equals to 0.

    Q(s,a)=V(s)+A(s,a)maxâ¡aQ(s,a)=V(s)+maxâ¡aA(s,a)âˆ’maxâ¡aA(s,a)V(s)=maxâ¡aQ(s,a) Q(s,a)=V(s)+A(s,a) \\ \max\limits_aQ(s,a)=V(s)+\max\limits_aA(s,a)-\max\limits_aA(s,a)\\V(s)=\max\limits_aQ(s,a) Q(s,a)=V(s)+A(s,a)amaxâ€‹Q(s,a)=V(s)+amaxâ€‹A(s,a)âˆ’amaxâ€‹A(s,a)V(s)=amaxâ€‹Q(s,a)

    So is the sol 2.

    Therefore the two sols:

    1.Set VÎ¸,Î±(s)=maxâ¡aâ€²QÎ¸,Î±,Î²(s,aâ€²)V_{\theta,\alpha}(s)=\max\limits_{a'}Q_{\theta,\alpha,\beta}(s,a')VÎ¸,Î±â€‹(s)=aâ€²maxâ€‹QÎ¸,Î±,Î²â€‹(s,aâ€²)

    QÎ¸,Î±,Î²(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±(s)+AÎ¸,Î²(s,a)âˆ’maxâ¡aâ€²AÎ¸,Î²(s,aâ€²) Q_{\theta,\alpha,\beta}(s,a) = V_{\theta,\alpha}(s)+A_{\theta,\beta}(s,a)-\max\limits_{a'}A_{\theta,\beta}(s,a') QÎ¸,Î±,Î²â€‹(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±â€‹(s)+AÎ¸,Î²â€‹(s,a)âˆ’aâ€²maxâ€‹AÎ¸,Î²â€‹(s,aâ€²)

    1. Set VÎ¸,Î±(s)=1âˆ£Aâˆ£âˆ‘aâ€²âˆˆAQÎ¸,Î±,Î²(s,aâ€²)V_{\theta,\alpha}(s)=\frac{1}{|A|}\sum_{a' \in A}Q_{\theta,\alpha,\beta}(s,a')VÎ¸,Î±â€‹(s)=âˆ£Aâˆ£1â€‹âˆ‘aâ€²âˆˆAâ€‹QÎ¸,Î±,Î²â€‹(s,aâ€²)

    QÎ¸,Î±,Î²(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±(s)+AÎ¸,Î²(s,a)âˆ’1âˆ£Aâˆ£âˆ‘aâ€²âˆˆAAÎ¸,Î²(s,aâ€²) Q_{\theta,\alpha,\beta}(s,a) = V_{\theta,\alpha}(s)+A_{\theta,\beta}(s,a)-\frac{1}{|A|}\sum_{a' \in A}A_{\theta,\beta}(s,a') QÎ¸,Î±,Î²â€‹(s,a)=VÎ¸,Î±â€‹(s)+AÎ¸,Î²â€‹(s,a)âˆ’âˆ£Aâˆ£1â€‹aâ€²âˆˆAâˆ‘â€‹AÎ¸,Î²â€‹(s,aâ€²)

    The sol ensure the uniqueness of V function,

    but not satisfy with the Bellman f, the outputs of A,V,Q of the network are no longer the real A,V,Q.

    We do not care of it, because the standard of doing greedy is the order of Q.

    The relative order of Q remains the same. s.t.Q(s,a1)>Q(s,a2)â†’A(s,a1)>A(s,a2)Q(s,a_1) > Q(s,a_2) \rightarrow A(s,a_1) > A(s,a_2)Q(s,a1â€‹)>Q(s,a2â€‹)â†’A(s,a1â€‹)>A(s,a2â€‹)$

    • +:
      • Handle states that are less associated with actions. æ²¡äººçš„è·¯ä¸Šæ€ä¹ˆå¼€éƒ½è¡Œã€‚
      • effective in learning state-value f: one state value function corresponds to multiple Advantage. functions. Share the same state-value function; Easy Training, fast convergence.

    Approximate Value Functions

    • vÎ¸(s)v_\theta(s)vÎ¸â€‹(s): approximate value of state $ s $ given parameter vector $ \theta $
    • qÎ¸(s,a)q_\theta(s, a)qÎ¸â€‹(s,a): approximate value of state-action pair $ (s, a) $ given parameter vector $ \theta $
    • âˆ‡vÎ¸(s)\nabla v_\theta(s)âˆ‡vÎ¸â€‹(s): column vector of partial derivatives of $ v_\theta(s) $ with respect to $ \theta $
    • âˆ‡qÎ¸(s,a)\nabla q_\theta(s, a)âˆ‡qÎ¸â€‹(s,a): column vector of partial derivatives of $ q_\theta(s, a) $ with respect to $ \theta $

    Bellman Operators

    • BÏ€B_\piBÏ€â€‹: Bellman operator for value functions
    • PPP: state-transition probability matrix under $ \pi $
    • DDD: diagonal matrix with on-policy state distribution on its diagonal
    • XXX: feature matrix, with $ x(s) $ as its rows
    • Î \PiÎ : projection operator for value functions

    Below are the missing symbols and notation that were not properly formatted in the original document:

    Symbols

    • f:Xâ†’Yf : X \to Yf:Xâ†’Y: function fff from elements of set XXX to elements of set YYY
    • (a,b](a, b](a,b]: the real interval between aaa and bbb including bbb but not including aaa
    • âˆˆ\inâˆˆ: is an element of; e.g., sâˆˆS,râˆˆRs \in S, r \in RsâˆˆS,râˆˆR
    • âŠ†\subseteqâŠ†: subset of; e.g., RâŠ†RR \subseteq \mathbb{R}RâŠ†R
    • âˆ£Sâˆ£|S|âˆ£Sâˆ£: number of elements in set SSS

    Temporal Difference Learning

    • Î´t\delta_tÎ´tâ€‹: temporal-difference (TD) error at time ttt
    • Î´ts,Î´ta\delta_t^s, \delta_t^aÎ´tsâ€‹,Î´taâ€‹: state- and action-specific forms of the TD error
    • nnn: in n-step methods, nnn is the number of steps of bootstrapping

    Eligibility Traces

    • w,wtw, w_tw,wtâ€‹: weight vector in function approximation
    • w,wt\mathbf{w}, \mathbf{w}_tw,wtâ€‹: weight vector notation
    • x(s)x(s)x(s): vector of features visible in state sss
    • x(s,a)x(s, a)x(s,a): vector of features visible in state sss taking action aaa
    • x(s)\mathbf{x}(s)x(s), x(s,a)\mathbf{x}(s, a)x(s,a): feature vectors in bold
    • wTx\mathbf{w}^T \mathbf{x}wTx: inner product of weight vector and feature vector

    Policy Gradient Methods

    • Î¸,Î¸t\theta, \theta_tÎ¸,Î¸tâ€‹: parameter vector of target policy
    • Ï€(aâˆ£s,Î¸)\pi(a | s, \theta)Ï€(aâˆ£s,Î¸): probability of taking action aaa in state sss given parameter Î¸\thetaÎ¸
    • âˆ‡Ï€(aâˆ£s,Î¸)\nabla \pi(a | s, \theta)âˆ‡Ï€(aâˆ£s,Î¸): gradient of policy function
    • J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸): performance measure for policy Ï€Î¸\pi_\thetaÏ€Î¸â€‹
    • âˆ‡J(Î¸)\nabla J(\theta)âˆ‡J(Î¸): gradient of performance measure
    • b(aâˆ£s)b(a|s)b(aâˆ£s): behavior policy used to select actions while learning about target policy Ï€\piÏ€

    Importance Sampling

    • Ït:h\rho_t:hÏtâ€‹:h: importance sampling ratio for time ttt through time hhh
    • Ït\rho_tÏtâ€‹: importance sampling ratio for time ttt alone, Ït=Ït:t\rho_t = \rho_{t:t}Ïtâ€‹=Ït:tâ€‹
    • r(Ï€)r(\pi)r(Ï€): average reward (reward rate) for policy Ï€\piÏ€

    Norms and Errors

    • âˆ¥vâˆ¥Î¼2\|v\|^2_{\mu}âˆ¥vâˆ¥Î¼2â€‹: Î¼\muÎ¼-weighted squared norm of value function vvv
    • âˆ¥Î´tâˆ¥2\|\delta_t\|^2âˆ¥Î´tâ€‹âˆ¥2: squared temporal-difference error
